title: Daniela Calzetti
text:
Daniela Calzetti is an Italian-American astronomer known for her research on <a href="cosmic%20dust">cosmic dust</a>, <a href="star%20formation">star formation</a>, and <a href="galaxy%20formation%20and%20evolution">galaxy formation and evolution</a>, and in particular for the Calzetti <a href="Extinction%20%28astronomy%29">dust extinction</a> law, an estimate for how much information about distant galaxies has been obscured by cosmic dust. She is a professor of astronomy and head of the astronomy department at the <a href="University%20of%20Massachusetts%20Amherst">University of Massachusetts Amherst</a>, and principal investigator of the Legacy ExtraGalactic Ultraviolet Survey project of the <a href="Hubble%20Space%20Telescope">Hubble Space Telescope</a>.
Education and career.
Calzetti is originally from <a href="Parma">Parma</a>. She earned a laurea in physics from <a href="Sapienza%20University%20of%20Rome">Sapienza University of Rome</a> in 1987, where she completed her Ph.D. in 1992, with the dissertation "Large-Scale Distribution of Galaxies and Clusters: The Scale of Inhomogeneity" supervised by <a href="Remo%20Ruffini">Remo Ruffini</a>.
She worked as a researcher for the <a href="Space%20Telescope%20Science%20Institute">Space Telescope Science Institute</a> from 1990 to 2007, when she moved to the University of Massachusetts Amherst.
Recognition.
Calzetti was elected to the <a href="National%20Academy%20of%20Sciences">National Academy of Sciences</a> in 2020.
